or(ğ´âˆ§ğµ)âˆ¨ğ¶=(ğ´âˆ¨ğ¶)âˆ§(ğµâˆ¨ğ¶) Inductively (ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘—ğ‘›=1â€¦ğ‘š and ğ‘—(ğ‘–) refers to taking all {1,â€¦,ğ‘›}â†’{1,â€¦,ğ‘š} functions)â‹€ğ‘–=1..ğ‘›â‹ğ‘—=1..ğ‘šğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—=â‹ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘—ğ‘›=1â€¦ğ‘šâ‹€ğ‘–=1..ğ‘›ğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—(ğ‘–) Similarlyâ‹ğ‘–=1..ğ‘›â‹€ğ‘—=1..ğ‘šğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—=â‹€ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘—ğ‘›=1â€¦ğ‘šâ‹ğ‘–=1..ğ‘›ğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—(ğ‘–) [bool-commutative-law] äº¤æ¢å¾‹ ğ´+ğµ=ğµ+ğ´. same for âˆ— [bool-associative-law] ç»“åˆå¾‹ (ğ´+ğµ)+ğ¶=ğ´+(ğµ+ğ¶). same for âˆ— [periodic-circuit] Periodic CircuitImplemented by crystal oscillators [memory-circuit] Circuit MemoryBlack box modelPossible implementationThe middle of the diagram uses a loop circuit to reuse the Bool value from the previous cycle. If write control is turned off, the values of read,read remain unchangedInverters (not gates) ensure current direction and prevent attenuation (via external energy)Suppose the value of the yellow part in the loop circuit is ğ‘, and the blue part is ğ‘. To write 0 into an existing ğ‘=1, a higher write voltage than the one in the loop circuit is needed to override the loop, i.e. using higher voltage write=1 thus ğ‘=1 to override the existing ğ‘=1 [finite-machine] Finite State Machine [i/o] The input of a circuit might come from the outside world (e.g. sensors, keyboards), and the output of a circuit might also go to the outside world (e.g. signal lights, screens)The rhythm of external inputs is usually inconsistent with the rhythm of the computerâ€™s internal periodic circuits, so the external inputs need to pass through synchronization components first [memory-array] Memory arrayExample 23 is the number of steps taken when counting from 000, 001, 010 to 111, although this assumes we can recognize three bits. 2ğ‘›=2â‹¯2âŸğ‘›-fold, 101=1âˆ—22+0âˆ—21+1âˆ—20=4+1=5Use the range of natural numbers contained in multiple bits, for example 3 bits 0,1,â€¦,7 as parameters, to correspond to real-world content. Example The representation of characters in a computer e.g. ASCII, Unicode, the position and color of pixels on a screen(image modified from wiki media about ASCII. Hex refers to hexadecimal)In practical applications, multiple bits per address is better than 1 bit per address, or rather, a two-dimensional memory array is more efficient than a one-dimensional one(p. 265 of ref-1) [instruction] æŒ‡ä»¤Control the computer to complete some circuit tasks through instructions. Instructions are also represented by binary (multi-bit data). The instruction stream is generated by the compiler based on the source code and stored in memory, then read and executed by the CPUSome common circuit tasksAddition of natural numbersJudging whether bit data meets the required conditions, for example, judging if ğ‘–>2Jumping to the execution of other instructionsAssume an instruction is completed within one circuit cycle (single-cycle computer)Example add instruction. add x_1 x_2. The bit data fields of the instruction are divided into three areas, representing different types of informationReading the add instructionThe add instruction at adress_0 (add x_1 x_2 as well as adress_1, adress 2 come from source code and compiler generation)The value adress_0 stored at the fixed memory address adress_of_instruction is read out, the data in the index area of the add instruction is sent to the control signal component (control unit), then control signals are calculated and output (too many details, see ref-1)Execute the add instructionThe output control signals are input to the memoryâ€™s control circuit components, reading out x_1 in adress_1 and x_2 in adress_2 from memory, and inputting them into the arithmetic component (ALU)Based on the output control signals, the output x_1 + x_2 from the arithmetic component is written to adress_1 (overwriting the value of x_1)Enter and fetch the instruction for the next cycleThe value adress_0 stored in adress_of_instruction is sent by the pre-designed circuit to the arithmetic component to calculate adress_0 + 1 i.e. the next instruction address, which is then written into the data within adress_of_instruction. adress_0 + 1 will be executed in the next circuit cycleOther instructions might have more than two data areas (non-instruction index areas)Instruction streamExample [loop] The speed of the cycle circuit is far higher than human speed (1 GHz = 10^9 cycles per second)Loops in high-level programming languageslet i : int = 0;while (i < 10) { i = i + 1;} // result = 10let i : int = 0;while (i < 10) { i = i + 1;} // result = 10Fetch instructionThe bgt (branch_grater_than) instruction is stored at adress_0. (Instructions are generated from source code and the compiler.) 10 is in one data area of bgt, and the number of instructions needed for the while loop 3 is in another data area of bgtExecute instructionExecute condition check ğ‘–<10Read out i and 10, compare their sizes in the arithmetic unit, give a control signal based on the result, and combine it with the control signal given by the bgt index areaAccording to the result of the conditional judgment, perform different tasksWhen ğ‘–<10The arithmetic unit outputs a control signal based on this judgment, changing the value stored in adress_of_instruction to the address of the next instruction adress_0 + 1The instruction at adress_0 + 1 needs to perform the task ğ‘–new=ğ‘–old+1Use the add instruction to calculate i + 1 and write it back to adress_1After executing add, go back to the judgment for the next loop ğ‘–<10?The instruction following the add instruction is a jump instruction at adress_0 + 2; its execution result is modifying the value of adress_of_instruction to adress_of_instruction - 2 = (adress_0 + 2) - 2 = adress_0, achieving an instruction jump to perform the next loop judgment ğ‘–<10?When ğ‘–â‰¥10The arithmetic unit outputs a control signal based on this bgt judgment, changing the value stored in adress_of_instruction to adress_0 + 3 instead of adress_0 + 1, jumping out of the while loop to execute the subsequent instructions [compile] [parse] Use a parser or compiler to verify the correctness of the token stream language; essentially, it traverses all language rules and then stores them in memory as structured data (some visual descriptions: tables, nodes, trees)One implementation method is recursive descent, enum + match (or if else) + recursionIf you want to make software run on a computer, you have to turn the token stream of the source code into structured data, and then into an instruction streamIf language rules are complex, they can be categorized and decomposed (multiple times), first traversing categories, then traversing rules within those categories. Example split into â€œsyntax checkâ€ and â€œsemantics checkâ€Heuristic examples of the concepts of abstraction and API (application programming interface): objects around you, you can use them conveniently without knowing their manufacturing principles, because they were designed that wayComputers, besides the advantage of high-speed periodic circuits, other advantages include memory storage capacity (1 GB = 2^(30+3) bit = 8589934592 bit) and memory persistence (power-on time)Complex data structures and calculation functions can be constructed in memory. This might also be useful for many other fieldsThe motivation for variables or variable names is that humans cannot memorize and process that many addresses; variable names are intended to use semantics to assist human memory and usage, and let computers handle addresses automaticallyVariables or variable names allow the values stored in memory to be reused through addresses, minimizing the memory and use of new addresses as much as possible

A real polynomial can be factored completely into products of the form (ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ‘) or (ğ‘¥2+ğ‘ğ‘¥+ğ‘)2, while the latter can be factored in â„‚ as (ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ‘)(ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ‘âˆ—), in particular, ğ‘¥2+1=(ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ¢)(ğ‘¥+ğ¢). We immediately encounter a problem: one definition of a linear map is as a homomorphism between linear spaces, but since â„ is non-commutative, scalar multiplication cannot arbitrarily commute with matrix multiplication on the same side ğ‘(ğ‘‡ğ‘¥)!=ğ‘‡(ğ‘ğ‘¥), thus matrix multiplication on â„ğ‘› is not a linear transformation.Therefore, the â€œlinear structureâ€ of â„ğ‘› is defined as, for example, left matrix multiplication acting as the linear map ğ‘‡ğ‘¥, and right scalar multiplication ğ‘¥ğ‘, such that the linear map is a homomorphism of the linear structure ğ‘‡(ğ‘¥ğ‘)=(ğ‘‡ğ‘¥)ğ‘.

38.body:
Typst BookOne argument for the rationality of the action principle is its simplicity: by simply adding connections and then adding actions, one can obtain interaction equations without having to guess how matter, electromagnetic fields, and gravitational fields interact.However, why the addition of actions is used, and whether the resulting interaction equations truly correspond to real phenomena, are not solved here â€¦Spinor fields, scalar fields, gauge fields, gravitational fields (Einstein-metric), or other fields are coupled in the following ways:Action summationgauge-connectionmetric-volume-formmetric-connectionâˆ«ğ‘€ğ‘‘Vol(ğ‘”)(spin+scalar+gauge+gravity) Varying with respect to 4 sets of variables gives 4 equationsspin
scalar
gauge
gravity We can set some fields to zero or fix certain fields to obtain partial coupling (for gravity, Î“=0 ==> flat-metric)In the equation, the 4-current of the field becomes the source of the gauge potential (spinor field 4-current scalar field 4-current point particle 4-current)

4.body: Typst BookAlthough integration on manifolds considers not being limited to a specific metric, differential manifolds have still not been singled out.The situation with fiber bundles is similar; the codomain and its symmetries seem uncertain in the general case.Examplehomogeneous spaceframe bundleprincipal-bundle-connectionSome intuition can be inspired by the specific symmetry space with the triple ğº,ğ»,ğºğ» as a fiber bundleEhresmann connectionThe connection on the tangent bundle is considered a generalization of the translation structure. The clue is that, Itâ€™s said that, the maximum dimension of the diffeomorphism that preserves the tangent bundle connection is the dimension of the affine group. One way to understand connections is the Ehresmann connection, viewed as a vertical-horizontal decomposition of the second-order tangent bundle âŠ¤âŠ¤ğ‘€, where the horizontal part might be a generalization of the â€œparallel transportâ€ of the tangent space during translation ğ‘+ğ‘£ (and thus not just translation alone), in an infinitesimal manner, indicating that when changing infinitesimally, in order for the connection or the associated vector field on âŠ¤ğ‘€ to generate a local tangent bundle automorphism of the tangent bundle âŠ¤ğ‘€ rather than a general local diffeomorphism of âŠ¤ğ‘€, this decomposition must also be linear with respect to the vertical part, or say that the transformation on the hole fiber space is GL(ğ‘›,â„).Let ğ‘Œ:ğ‘€â†’âŠ¤ğ‘€ be a tangent vector field. Its differential ğ‘‘ğ‘Œ:âŠ¤ğ‘ğ‘€â†’âŠ¤ğ‘Œğ‘ğ‘€ maps ğ‘‹âˆˆâŠ¤ğ‘ğ‘€ to ğ‘‘ğ‘Œğ‘(ğ‘‹)âˆˆâŠ¤ğ‘Œğ‘(âŠ¤ğ‘€). connection gives a projection to the vertical subbundle ğ‘ƒ:âŠ¤(âŠ¤ğ‘€)â†’ğ‘‰, then after the canonical isomorphism from the vertical subbundle to the tangent bundle, we get covariant derivative âˆ‡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(ğ‘). A connection is called flat if it satisfies the following equivalent conditionsthe connection makes the horizontal subbundle ğ» integrablethe curvature is zerothere exists a local coordinate system where âˆ‡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ=ğœ•ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ, i.e., in this coordinate system, the connection coefficients are zero and the covariant derivative is the coordinate derivativeThe concept of a geodesic is weaker than that of a connection; a geodesic depends only on the symmetrical part of a connection.â€œThe transformation of the entire fiber space under â€œparallel transportâ€ is GL(ğ‘›,â„)â€œ can be generalized to other non-tangent bundle fiber bundles. For example, in gauge theory, there are cases where the transformation of the entire fiber space under parallel transport is ğ‘ˆ(1). Or consider a Lie group ğº acting/represented on a fiber manifold ğ‘‹, then the transformation of the entire fiber space under parallel transport is ğº acting on ğ‘‹. All of these can be reduced to principal bundles â€” ğº acting on the fiber ğº â€” and their associated bundles. The concept of flat connection also applies

Typst BookFor humans, one way to understand natural numbers is counting.For computers (cf. logic.typ), the source of representing natural numbers is periodic circuits. The binary in memory can directly represent numbers. For example, for 3 bits:binarydecimal00000011010201131004101511061117A computerâ€™s arithmetic unit can perform +1 calculations on numbers.There are also various more complex computer behaviors like â€œfunctions that recursively call themselvesâ€, which is also a form of counting.However, the number of elements in the set of natural numbers is infinite, while bits and computer memory are finite. Human memory is also finite.Problem of infinite space: Reality cannot construct circuits and memory of infinite space. Even if it could, it would be limited by the finite speed of electric current.But â€œpotential infinityâ€ can be achieved using potentially infinite time.Assuming the upper limit of memory is infinite but memory usage per cycle is finite, then a program has infinitely possible inputs, which is also a form of potential infinity.Theoretically, all natural numbers can be counted one by one. However, there are even sets with an uncountable number of elements. They are infinite and cannot be counted. ExampleAll subsets of â„•, Subset(â„•) or â„•â†’{0,1} (i.e., all functions from â„• to {0,1}=Bool)All functions from â„• to itself, â„•â†’â„•Verifying the correctness of set theory/languages requires a parser, or for mathematical languages, also called a prover.Motivation for sets/typesModularity and multiplicative decomposition to simplify cognitionExample The subject-verb-object SVO in natural language. Suppose there are 10 nouns and 10 verbs. If we â€œforgot the SVO rulesâ€, then verifying the grammatical correctness of a three-word sentence would require at most 103=1000 attempts. If we understand and use SVO rules, it would require at most 23=8 attempts.If the number of elements in a set is infinite, then the set/type will be conceptually finite, making it possible to state within a finite timeComplex mathematical objects are stored in variable names, so humans still need to check the correctness of all complex definitions stored in variable names, which is why code readability is very importantA prover allows humans to reduce from needing to review all steps to reviewing definitions (and checking the compilerâ€™s logical code), skipping a large number of detailed proof steps, and still being able to determine the correctness of the proof resultThe human brain compiler can omit and supplement omissions, trading temporary efficiency for error-proneness and forgetfulnessIn addition to verifying the correctness of proofs, provers can also have other uses, for example, similar to tools in programming languages, they can have friendly and interactive compiler error messages, and LSP (language server protocol) toolsprover çš„ä¾‹å­: acornprover, leanLetâ€™s not go into details here for now, just a brief overview [proposition] [theorem] An unproved proposition/theorem ğ‘ is a function from type ğ‘‡ to Bool, ğ‘:ğ‘‡â†’Booltheorem p(x: T) { // ...}theorem p(x: T) { // ...}ğ‘ is proven := the proverâ€™s calculation result for ğ‘ always returns true. After extension, ğµâˆª{ğ‘} is also a chain [maximal-linear-order-exists] maximal-linear-order chain alaways existsAlso known as the Zorn LemmaRequires Axiom of Choice: If it can be proven that some sets (of a certain type) have elements with a certain property, then a function can be defined that maps these sets to the corresponding elements.Proof zorn_lemma.ac in my github repo ac-math ref-30

But the use of metric or the use of kinetic energy is not the Killing-form of ğ—Œğ—ˆ(3), because for objects that are not uniformly mass-distributed spheres, rotations in different directions have different inertias. Moment of inertia i.e. metric ğ‘” may need to be calculated additionallyThe moment of inertia can also be used as a symmetric operator under the Killing-form, with the characteristic basis being the principal axes of inertia and the eigenvalues being the moments of inertia.

71.body: Typst BookA net system := ğ‘‹ where each point has a net ğ(ğ‘¥).Example The point net system composed of all spheres ğ”¹(ğ‘¥,ğ‘Ÿ) in Euclidean spaceA net system is not sufficient as a definition of a topological space. Then the closure of {1} is {1,2}, and its closure again is {1,2,3} [topology] defined as a net system + limit separation of interior and exterior of any set ğ´Interior ğ‘¥âˆˆint(ğ´)â‰”âˆƒğµâˆˆğ(ğ‘¥),ğµâŠ†ğ´Exterior ğ‘¥âˆˆext(ğ´)â‰”âˆƒğµâˆˆğ(ğ‘¥),ğµâŠ†ğ´âˆLimit separationâˆ€ğ‘¥âˆˆint(ğ´),âˆƒğµ(ğ‘¥)âˆˆğ(ğ‘¥),ğµ(ğ‘¥)âŠ†int(ğ´)âˆ€ğ‘¦âˆˆext(ğ´),âˆƒğµ(ğ‘¦)âˆˆğ(ğ‘¦),ğµ(ğ‘¦)âŠ†ext(ğ´)Boundary defined as bd(ğ´)â‰”ğ‘‹âˆ–(int(ğ´)âˆªext(ğ´)). It seems that preserving the limit is not as strong as continuity. Typst BookThe direction space of Euclidean â„2 is {(ğ‘¥,ğ‘¦)âˆˆâ„2:ğ‘¥2+ğ‘¦2=1}=ğ•Š1On the direction space ğ•Š1 of â„2, one can also define the â€œdistanceâ€ between any two points ğ‘,ğ‘âˆˆğ•Š1: by restricting the â€œmetricâ€ of â„2 to ğ•Š1, we obtain the metric of ğ•Š1, and then using the metric of ğ•Š1, we can define the distance on ğ•Š1 as the length of the shortest geodesic connecting the two pointsMaps that preserve the metric of â„2 are called isometries of â„2. It can be proven that isometries of â„2 are affine maps. The (orientation-preserving) isometries of â„2 are SO(2)â‹Šâ„2. The part of the isometries that fixes the origin is SO(2), which also preserves the direction space ğ•Š1 of â„2 and preserves the metric on ğ•Š1, thereby preserving the distance on ğ•Š1SO(2) is called rotationElements of SO(2) are {(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘):ğ‘2+ğ‘2=1}. Set-theoretically equivalent to {(ğ‘,ğ‘):ğ‘2+ğ‘2=1}=ğ•Š1(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)âŸ·(ğ‘,ğ‘) The action of SO(2) on SO(2) and on ğ•Š1 is compatible(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)(10)=(ğ‘ğ‘) for(10)âˆˆğ•Š1
(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)(11)=(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘) for(11)âˆˆSO(2) Thus, we can define multiplication on ğ‘§,ğ‘§â€²âˆˆğ•Š1 as the corresponding multiplication of SO(2)ğ‘§â‹…ğ‘§â€²=(ğ‘,ğ‘)â‹…(ğ‘â€²,ğ‘â€²)â‰ƒ(ğ‘ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘)(ğ‘â€²ğ‘â€²âˆ’ğ‘â€²ğ‘â€²)
=â‹¯
â‰ƒ(ğ‘ğ‘â€²âˆ’ğ‘ğ‘â€²,ğ‘â€²ğ‘+ğ‘ğ‘â€²) At the same time, because SO(2) are linear maps, the distributive law holdsğ‘§â‹…(ğ‘§â€²+ğ‘§â€³)=ğ‘§â‹…ğ‘§â€²+ğ‘§â‹…ğ‘§â€³ [complex-numbler-geometric-meaning] This is equivalent to the multiplication of unit complex numbers. Since rotations SO(2) and scalar multiplication â„ commute, the multiplication on unit complex numbers can be easily extended to multiplication on complex numbers â„‚ [angle] AngleIt may not be a perfect motivationIntuitively, in Euclidean â„2, we can â€œrotateâ€, and the composition of rotations corresponds to the addition of â€œanglesâ€Angle should be the distance on ğ•Š1, the distance along the shortest geodesic connecting two points.The rotation we defined is the group preserving the ğ•Š1 distance, which hasnâ€™t directly explained the intuitive sense of rotation.Intuitively, we know that on ğ•Š1, we can continuously define a â€œpositive direction of the tangent spaceâ€ for each pointFor (ğ‘,ğ‘)âˆˆğ•Š1, the positive direction of the tangent space is (âˆ’ğ‘,ğ‘)âˆˆâŠ¤ğ•Š1One can guess that the intuitive rotation is moving each point on ğ•Š1 along the positive direction by a distance/radian/angle of ğœƒThe question is, how to understand that SO(2), which preserves the ğ•Š1 distance (and orientation), is equivalent to this intuitive rotation?At least from the result, I knowThe positive direction tangent field ğ‘‹=(âˆ’ğ‘,ğ‘) is an infinitesimal isometry (called a Killing field), which is the Lie algebra of the isometry group. And moving each point along the positive direction by a distance ğœƒ (along the geodesic) is the way to generate an isometry from an infinitesimal isometry, i.e., the exp of the Lie algebra.Since geodesics are a kind of integral curve along a vector field, the addition of distances is homomorphic to the multiplication of group actionsexp((ğœƒ1+ğœƒ2)ğ‘‹)=exp(ğœƒ1ğ‘‹)â‹…exp(ğœƒ2ğ‘‹) This also gives commutativityexp(ğœƒ1ğ‘‹)â‹…exp(ğœƒ2ğ‘‹)=exp(ğœƒ2ğ‘‹)â‹…exp(ğœƒ1ğ‘‹) For the geodesic coordinates starting from (10)âˆˆğ•Š1, the result is denoted as [trigonometric-function] trigonometric functions (cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ)).According to the correspondence between SO(2) multiplication and ğ•Š1 multiplication, we know that (cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ)âˆ’sin(ğœƒ)cos(ğœƒ))(10)=(cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ))Therefore (cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ)âˆ’sin(ğœƒ)cos(ğœƒ)) is also the action of rotating other points on ğ•Š1 by ğœƒAccording to the homomorphism(cos(ğ‘ +ğ‘¡)sin(ğ‘ +ğ‘¡)âˆ’sin(ğ‘ +ğ‘¡)cos(ğ‘ +ğ‘¡))=(cos(ğ‘ )sin(ğ‘ )âˆ’sin(ğ‘ )cos(ğ‘ ))(cos(ğ‘¡)sin(ğ‘¡)âˆ’sin(ğ‘¡)cos(ğ‘¡)) According to the power series representation of exp, and that the unit tangent vector in the positive direction at (10) is (01) corresponding to (1âˆ’1)(cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ)âˆ’sin(ğœƒ)cos(ğœƒ))=âˆ‘ğ‘›=0..âˆ1ğ‘›!(1âˆ’1)ğ‘›ğœƒğ‘› we can obtaincos(ğœƒ)=âˆ‘(âˆ’1)ğ‘›(2ğ‘›)!ğœƒ2ğ‘›
sin(ğœƒ)=âˆ‘(âˆ’1)ğ‘›(2ğ‘›+1)!ğœƒ2ğ‘›+1 Expressed using complex numbers, (1âˆ’1)â‰ƒğ¢(cos(ğœƒ)sin(ğœƒ)âˆ’sin(ğœƒ)cos(ğœƒ))â‰ƒâˆ‘ğ‘›=0..âˆ1ğ‘›!(ğ¢ğœƒ)ğ‘›=ğ‘’ğ¢ğœƒ=cosğ‘¡+ğ¢sinğ‘¡ and we have SO(2)â‰ƒU(1,â„‚)Â±ğ¢â‰”(0Â±1)=(cos(Â±ğœ‹2)sin(Â±ğœ‹2))â‰ƒ(Â±1âˆ’(Â±1))ğ¢âˆ’1=âˆ’ğ¢ or âˆ’ğ¢2=1 or ğ¢2=âˆ’1Complex conjugation preserves distance but reverses direction (|ğ‘§|ğ‘’ğ¢ğ‘¡)âˆ—=|ğ‘§|ğ‘’âˆ’ğ¢ğ‘¡ or (ğ‘¥+ğ¢ğ‘¦)âˆ—=ğ‘¥âˆ’ğ¢ğ‘¦Similarly, hyperbolic â„1,1 and split complex â„‚splitexp(Im(â„‚)) give U(1,â„‚)â‰ƒğ•Š1â‰ƒSO(2)exp(Im(â„‚split)) give U(1,â„‚split)â‰ƒâ„ğ•ª1â‰ƒSO(1,1)Question Generalize to quaternions â„ and octonions ğ•† and their split versionsConversely, if we accept the concept that angles are additive (homomorphism), then it provides motivation for: the Euclidean norm of â„2 being âˆšğ‘¥21+ğ‘¥22 and not some other norm. But you can also use ğ‘â‡(ğ‘ğ‘â—Š) to get the true square (ğ‘ğ‘â—Š)2=(detğ‘)ğŸ™Since (ğ‘ğ‘â—Š)2â‰ (detğ‘)ğŸ™, the transformation (ğ‘ğ‘â—Š)â‡(ğ‘â—Šğ‘) does not come from GL(4,â„‚) coordinate change ğ‘‡âˆ’1â‹…ğ‘€â‹…ğ‘‡ [motivation-of-gauge-field] Ignored some issuesTangent projective light cone bundle is well-definedBut is a â„‚2 field or a â„‚â„™1 field needed? There are too many choices to lift a â„‚â„™1 field to a â„‚2 field (or to a â„‚2âˆ–0 field); all lifting choices form a GL(1,â„‚)=â„>0Ã—U(1) fieldAnd there are only two ways to lift SO(1,3) to SL(2,â„‚)On a curved manifold, there may not even be a global single-valued lift.The change in the lifting method from a â„‚â„™1 field to a â„‚2 field corresponds to â€œchanging the gaugeâ€, by multiplying the spinor ğœ™(ğ‘¥) by ğ‘(ğ‘¥)=|ğ‘(ğ‘¥)|exp(ğœƒğ¢) to change the gauge.If the conserved current of the action is to be simpler, then use U(1) gauge transformation instead of GL(1,â„‚)=U(1)Ã—â„>0. U(1) does not change the Lagrangian action, which simplifies the calculation of conserved currents (cf. the case of scalar field calculating 4-current for U(1) symmetry).Changing the gauge is not compatible with taking derivatives of tangent spaces in bundle coordinates, so an additional structure â€” connection â€” must be introduced.There are many possible connections. A good connection is one with the smallest curvature cf. electromagnetic-fieldThe â„‚2 bundle in curved spacetime can be directly defined in the bundle coordinates of the SO(1,3) principal bundle (orthonormal frame bundle). Using the SL(1,â„‚)â† SO(1,3) correspondence, changing SO(1,3) bundle coordinates automatically corresponds to changing SL(2,â„‚) bundle coordinates.In curved spacetime, one needs to deal with the covariant derivative of the spinor field with respect to the metric, which is derived from the metric-connection of the tangent vector field.For spinors, one might need to use an orthonormal frame instead of a coordinate frame, i.e., use SO(1,3),SL(2,â„‚) principal bundle. Does this introduce new difficulties for calculating covariant derivatives?Even if the topology of the spacetime base manifold is non-trivial, there might exist different bundle types for gauge fields.One problem is that, unlike spinor fields, gauge bundles do not seem to be directly related to tangent bundles.It seems that all types of U(1) bundle types based on the base manifold must be considered simultaneously.In the homotopy sense, â„ğ‘,ğ‘ has only one type of U(1) bundle type. [spinor-field-gauge-imaginary-automorphism] Although the cost is using 1+9 dimensional spacetime, tangent space â„1,9, but if we consider octonions ğ•†, and if we choose a unit imaginary element ğ¢ to construct the spinor Lagrangian, then the octonionâ€™s imaginary automorphism group ğº2â€˜s isotropy on ğ¢ leads to the decomposition â„‚+â„‚3, the isotropy group is isomorphic to SU(3), and it derives the action of SU(3) on â„‚3. cf. (ref-19, th.4)Note that the octonion imaginary automorphism group ğº2 is not U(1,ğ•†)â‰ƒğ•Š7. So this is not a group of gauge connection in the traditional sense.It is said that SU(3) is the gauge group of strong interaction. The advantage of the octonion method here is that there is no longer a need to additionally assume the separate existence of â„‚3 and SU(3) and perform tensor operations on â„‚3 and Dirac spinor out of thin air. The tensor from â„‚3 comes from the connection of ğ—(1,ğ•†)â‰ƒIm(ğ•†)=ğ¢+â„‚3 acting on the spinor ğ•†2 or ğ•†2+ğ•†2â—Š.The isotropy in ğº2 isomorphic to SU(3) will change the ğ—(1,ğ•†) phase or the ğ—(1,ğ•†) gauge field of the U(1,ğ•†) gauge transformation, leading to the SU(3) action on the â„‚3 part. Should it be said that there is a ğ—Œğ—(3) gauge field of the SU(3)â†ªğº2 gauge transformation for the ğ—(1,ğ•†) or â„‚3 gauge field of a U(1,ğ•†) gauge transformation, and then introduce the Yangâ€“Mills eq of minimal curvature again like the electromagnetic field?Question What about the case of quaternions â„? In the case of â„‚, the symmetry group of imaginary unit is â„¤2. When fixing one imaginary unit, it become ğŸ™In octonion spinor theory, there is still ğ•†2 as the space where the spinor field resides, the â„1,9 projective light cone is ğ•Š8â‰ƒğ•†â„™1, SL(2,ğ•†) gives a double cover of SO(1,9), and 1+9 spacetime corresponds to a second-order Hermitian octonion matrix â„2(ğ•†)=(ğ‘¡âˆ’ğ‘ğ›¼âˆ—ğ›¼ğ‘¡+ğ‘), where det corresponds to the spacetime metric. Moreover, spacetime, spinor (ğœ™ğœ“), and a real number can be embedded into a third-order Hermitian octonion matrix â„3(ğ•†)â‰ƒâ„2(ğ•†)+ğ•†2+â„=(ğ‘Ÿğ•†ğ•†âˆ—â„2(ğ•†)) (and the projectivization ğ•†â„™2 of â„3(ğ•†) is a generalization of the â„1,9 projective light cone ğ•†â„™1), the group that preserves the det of â„3(ğ•†) is ğ¸6, which can be well embedded into SL(2,ğ•†)â† SO(1,9) and spinor gauge theory and SU(3)Ã—SU(2)Ã—U(1)â„¤6 cf. (ref-20, th.6)The quark lepton fermion model of the Standard Model can be written as S(U(2)U(3)) acting on â‹€(â„‚5), so some people embed S(U(2)U(3)) into Spin(4)Ã—Spin(6) (probably through U(2)â†ªSpin(4)â‰ƒSU(2)Ã—SU(2), ğ‘ˆ(3)â†ªSpin(6)â‰ƒSU(4)), and then embed it into Spin(10), and then correspond â‹€(â„‚5) with Cliff(10). These embeddings are called â€œGUTâ€. Spin(10) breaks to Spin(4)Ã—Spin(6)Mathematically, I think we can consider whether Spin(1,3)Ã—Spin(6) has something similar to the GUT quark lepton model, note that it is similar not identicalThe motivation for considering this model is that Spin(1,9)=SL(2,ğ‘‚)âŠ†SL(3,ğ‘‚)=ğ¸6(âˆ’26), and the spinor ğ•†2 and â‹€(â„‚5), Cliff(10) are very close, so that no additional assumption of â‹€(â„‚5) is needed, and the breaking may be completed by fixing a unit imaginary element, or equivalently fixing â„‚âŠ†ğ•†. [spin-connection] The frame bundle of SO(1,3) derived from the tangent bundle metric and the connection of the SO(1,3) frame bundle derived from metric-connection behave as Î“ is locally type (â„1,3)âŠºâŠ—ğ—Œğ—ˆ(1,3), acting on â„1,3 tangent vector fields by ğœ•+Î“The way to derive the spin-connection is to map the ğ—Œğ—ˆ(1,3) part of the induced metric-connection Î“ to ğ—Œğ—…(2,â„‚) in the orthonormal-frame, yielding the connection of the SL(2,â„‚) bundle, locally type (â„1,3)âŠºâŠ—â„‚2, acting on the spinor field â„‚2 by ğœ•+ğœ” with ğœ”=ğœ”ğœ‡ğœˆ14[ğœğœ‡,ğœğœˆ]â—ŠAlthough the definition of the Pauli matrix ğœ for spin representation requires ğ‘”, both ğ‘” and Lie algebra can be expressed by the â€œsquareâ€ of ğœ thereafter.spin-connection also denoted by âˆ‡ [motivation-of-scalar-field] can scalar field be related to tautological bundle of projective-lightcone â„‚â„™1?According to the concept of spinor fields in â„1,3 spacetime manifold, â€œrotation by 720 degreesâ€ and â€œparityâ€ should occur in the tangent space construction, not in the spacetime manifold.Since the tangent spaces of the spacetime manifold are all â„1,3, can spinor fields be generalized to general spacetime manifolds? [spinor-on-Lorentz-manifold] Questionmassless-spinor-actionâˆ«ğ‘‘Vol(ğ‘”)(ğœ“â€ ğ¢âˆ‡â—Šğœ“) massless-spinor-equationâˆ‡â—Šğœ“=0 I havenâ€™t verified if this definition is conceptually reasonable. Compare with flat spacetime, try to prove or disprove it.ğ¢âˆ‡â—Š is self-adjointOnly Re(ğœ“â€ âˆ‡â—Šğœ“) contributes to the variation of the action.âˆ‡â—Šâˆ‡=âˆ‡âˆ‡â—Š=12(âˆ‡â€ âˆ‡+âˆ‡âˆ‡â€ ) i.e. square-root-of spacetime Laplacian (closer to the Laplacian of tangent vector fields rather than scalar fields)massive-spinor-Lagrangianâˆ«ğ‘‘Vol(ğ‘”)(ğœ™ğœ“)â€ ((ğ¢âˆ‡â—Šğ¢âˆ‡)+ğ‘š(ğŸ™ğŸ™))(ğœ™ğœ“) massive-spinor-equation((ğ¢âˆ‡â—Šğ¢âˆ‡)+ğ‘š(ğŸ™ğŸ™))(ğœ™ğœ“)=0 Question As long as it locally quotients back from â„‚2 to â„‚â„™1, it can avoid the problem of continuous global single-valued lift to â„‚2.We know that the KG eq has a non-relativity approximation limit limğ‘â†’âˆ. Does the massive-spinor construction have a non-relativity approximation limit limğ‘â†’âˆ?Static doesnâ€™t need a non-relativity approximation limit limğ‘â†’âˆ, despite the presence of ğ‘, just like static electromagnetic field equations donâ€™t need a non-relativity approximation limit limğ‘â†’âˆ. This is also true for the KG equation.let ğœ™(ğ‘¡,ğ‘¥)=ğœ™(ğ‘¥) staticstatic massless spinor eqğœğ‘–ğœ•ğ‘–ğœ™=0 static massive spinor eq((âˆ’ğ¢ğœğ‘–ğœ•ğ‘–ğ¢ğœğ‘–ğœ•ğ‘–)+ğ‘šğ‘â„(ğŸ™ğŸ™))(ğœ™ğœ“)=0 They can couple to static electromagnetic gauge potential (ğ‘‰(ğ‘¥),ğ´1,2,3(ğ‘¥)) or just static electric ğ‘‰(ğ‘¥) or just static magnetic ğ´1,2,3(ğ‘¥)In the presence of electromagnetic potential, the parity dual of massless particles might be different, for example, just static electric ğœğ‘–ğœ•ğ‘–ğœ™Â±ğ¢ğ‘‰ğœ™=0When electromagnetic potential = 0, the parity dual eq is the same.
